questions.title: Working Capital and Liquidity
questions.question:
Which of the following is most likely a secondary source of liquidity?

  1. Bank line of credit
  2. Inventory liquidation
  3. Trade credit
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because it is a primary source of liquidity. Correct. Trade credit and a bank line of credit are considered primary sources of liquidity. Liquidating inventory is a secondary source of liquidity. Incorrect because it is a primary source of liquidity. Working Capital and Liquidity explain liquidity and compare issuers’ liquidity levels
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because it is a primary source of liquidity.

  2. Correct. Trade credit and a bank line of credit are considered primary sources of liquidity. Liquidating inventory is a secondary source of liquidity.

  3. Incorrect because it is a primary source of liquidity.

questions.title: Working Capital and Liquidity
questions.question: An issuer changing its credit terms for customers from 2/10, net 30 to 2/10, net 40 will most likely experience:
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. By extending the net period, the issuer will likely see its accounts receivable increase, lengthening its cash conversion cycle and producing a drag on its liquidity. A is incorrect, because the change will slow payments from customers (inflows) rather than pull on liquidity in terms of outflows. C is incorrect, because extending the net period will slow payments from customers and produce a drag on liquidity.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. By extending the net period, the issuer will likely see its accounts receivable increase, lengthening its cash conversion cycle and producing a drag on its liquidity.

A is incorrect, because the change will slow payments from customers (inflows) rather than pull on liquidity in terms of outflows.

C is incorrect, because extending the net period will slow payments from customers and produce a drag on liquidity.

questions.title: Working Capital and Liquidity
questions.question: Which of the following will most likely decrease an issuer’s cash conversion cycle? An increase in its days:
questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. Increasing days payable outstanding would reduce the cash conversion cycle, because payments to suppliers are delayed. Days payable outstanding is subtracted from the sum of days sales outstanding and days of inventory on hand to compute the cash conversion cycle. A is incorrect, because an increase in days sales outstanding will increase the issuer’s cash conversion cycle. B is incorrect, because an increase in days of inventory on hand will increase the issuer’s cash conversion cycle.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. Increasing days payable outstanding would reduce the cash conversion cycle, because payments to suppliers are delayed. Days payable outstanding is subtracted from the sum of days sales outstanding and days of inventory on hand to compute the cash conversion cycle.

A is incorrect, because an increase in days sales outstanding will increase the issuer’s cash conversion cycle.

B is incorrect, because an increase in days of inventory on hand will increase the issuer’s cash conversion cycle.

questions.question:
Data for a firm are presented in the following table:
As of 31 December £ Thousands
Cash 200
Accounts receivable 350
Inventory 1,250
Accounts payable 300
Taxes payable 200
Installment loan payable, due in three equal annual payments on 30 June. 600

The current ratio for the firm’s industry is 3.2. Based on the current ratio, the firm’s liquidity compared with the industry is best described as being:

  1. higher.
  2. equivalent.
  3. lower.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Failing to include the taxes payable or the loan (or the A/P) gives 1,800/400 = 4.5, which is above the industry average. Incorrect. The firm’s current ratio is 2.6, which is below the industry average. Correct. The higher the current ratio, the more liquid the company. Thus, with a current ratio of 2.6 (1,800/700), the company is less liquid than the industry, which has a current ratio of 3.2. Current ratio = Current assets/Current liabilities. questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Failing to include the taxes payable or the loan (or the A/P) gives 1,800/400 = 4.5, which is above the industry average.

  2. Incorrect. The firm’s current ratio is 2.6, which is below the industry average.

  3. Correct. The higher the current ratio, the more liquid the company. Thus, with a current ratio of 2.6 (1,800/700), the company is less liquid than the industry, which has a current ratio of 3.2.

questions.title: Working Capital and Liquidity
questions.question: An analyst is evaluating an issuer’s liquidity and calculates a negative cash conversion cycle for the issuer in the most recent fiscal year. This result is:

choices.B: possible, because the issuer has sufficient cash and marketable securities on hand to support short-term needs.
choices.C: possible, because the investment in inventory is returned quickly and the issuer takes advantage of vendor financing.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. If days of inventory on hand is low, the accounts receivable collection period is short, and the issuer takes advantage of its vendors’ financing, a negative cash conversion cycle is a possible result. A is incorrect, because issuers may have a negative cash conversion cycle if days payable outstanding is larger than the sum of days of inventory on hand and days sales outstanding. B is incorrect, because the amount of cash and marketable securities on hand does not affect the company’s cash conversion cycle.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. If days of inventory on hand is low, the accounts receivable collection period is short, and the issuer takes advantage of its vendors’ financing, a negative cash conversion cycle is a possible result.

A is incorrect, because issuers may have a negative cash conversion cycle if days payable outstanding is larger than the sum of days of inventory on hand and days sales outstanding.

B is incorrect, because the amount of cash and marketable securities on hand does not affect the company’s cash conversion cycle.

questions.title: Working Capital and Liquidity
questions.question: An issuer eliminated the prompt-payment discount it had offered to customers. This action most likely will:
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct , because the elimination of the discount will likely result in customers paying later as there is no incentive to pay early without the discount. With customers paying later, this action becomes a drag on liquidity. A and C are incorrect, because customers likely paying later will reduce the issuer’s liquidity.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct, because the elimination of the discount will likely result in customers paying later as there is no incentive to pay early without the discount. With customers paying later, this action becomes a drag on liquidity.

A and C are incorrect, because customers likely paying later will reduce the issuer’s liquidity.
